Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to provide a mechanistic explanation on the relationship between the ultrastructural (i.e. mineral and collagen) and bulk (tissue level) mechanical behavior of bone and to elucidate the ultrastructural origins of bone fragility fractures. To do so, a novel synchrotron X-ray diffraction based approach will be developed to fully capture the in situ behavior (e.g. strain tensors, residual strain status, damage accumulation, and viscous response) of mineral crystals and collagen fibrils in bone under load. Since the in situ behavior will be obtained simultaneously with measurements of bulk properties of bone, the relationship between the nanomechanics and bulk behavior of bone can be readily established under different loading conditions. Studies under this award will apply X-ray diffraction, crystal physics and biomechanics tools to distinguish the in situ behavior of individual group of crystals and collagen fibrils and its correlation with the bulk behavior of bone samples.

If successful, this study would enable us to identify the ultrastructural origins that dominate the bulk deformation/failure processes of bone. This will provide a rigorous foundation for accurate prediction of bone behaviors at ultrastructural levels and benefit for multiscale modeling of the tissue. The methodologies of this study may be readily extended to studying pathological changes of bone in animal models, thus providing a unique opportunity to study the interplay between bone biology and biomechanics in different bone disorders. This in turn may help develop the therapeutic regimens that specifically target the ultrastructural causes of bone fragility fractures. The educational plan is focused on student raining at graduate, undergraduate, and high school levels, course development in Skeletal Tissue Mechanics and Advanced Biomechanics, and recruitment of underrepresented students to participate in interdisciplinary research programs in cooperation with the Research Center for Minority Institutions at UTSA.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project supported by this award has achieved the major goal of the research: that is, to develop a novel semi-empirical technique to understand the biomechanics of bone at ultrastructural levels using an advanced synchrotron X-ray scattering approach and its correlation with the bulk behavior of the tissue. This will give rise to a unique tool for studying the ultrastructural origins of bone fragility fractures induced by aging and skeletal disorders by examining changes in the local deformation (i.e. the orientation dependent strain tensor of mineral phase) in the tissue under load. This novel methodology is developed based on several rigorous mathematic techniques (e.g. orientation and strain pole figure inversions, spherical harmonic, and quaternions). The efficacy of this novel approach is experimentally verified by testing bone samples from well-defined models. A major impact of this methodology is that this technique, for the first time, provides direct and quantitative measurements of local behavior of mineral crystals in different (i.e. intrafibrillar and extrafibrillar) compartments of bone matrix, concurrently with the measurement of the associated bulk properties of the tissue. Using this novel technique, we have investigated (1) ultrastructural origins of differences in bone properties between tension and compression loading modes, and (2) the effect of water on the ultrastructural behavior of bone and its role in sustaining the toughness of the tissue. Such information could not be otherwise obtained in the past. In the meantime, we have published the research results in a technical journal and presented them in several national/international conferences. Several journal papers are under preparation and will be submitted for publication soon. Currently, we are modifying the technique to facilitate its use in study of ultrastructural origins of bone fragility fractures using animal models. As the educational outcomes, a total of 7 graduate and 2 undergraduate students have been trained under the support of this award. Among them, one undergraduate student has proceeded to pursue a master degree in engineering, some have graduated with MS/ME degree and started working as engineers, and some are preparing to graduate soon.
